Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will be comprised of an integrated experimental and theoretical investigation of pilot-wave hydrodynamics, as arises when droplets propel themselves along the surface of a vibrating fluid bath through resonant interaction with their own wave field. Discovered by Yves Couder in 2005, the bouncing droplet system is reminiscent of the pilot-wave model of quantum dynamics postulated by Louis de Broglie as a rational alternative to the Copenhagen Interpretation, and exhibits several features once thought to be exclusive to the microscopic, quantum realm, including tunneling, orbital quantization and wavelike statistics. The research will be directed towards elucidating the manner in which this quantum-like behavior arises. Particular attention will be given to demonstrating how pilot-wave dynamics in the presence of an external force gives rise to quantized states, and ultimately to chaotic trajectories with wave-like statistics. The starting point will be a stability analysis of orbital solutions arising for drops walking in a rotating frame, and in the presence of a central force. Laboratory experiments will guide the theoretical developments, and new quantum analog systems will be explored. Once the behavior of this hydrodynamic system is thoroughly understood, we will investigate the link between the bouncing droplets and quantum particles, their statistics and dynamics. In addition to the direct educational value of this research to the graduate and undergraduate students involved, it will encourage communication across traditionally disparate disciplines, between workers in fluid dynamics, quantum physics and dynamical systems.

Einstein insisted that the statistical description of microscopic particles provided by standard quantum theory is incomplete, and underlaid by a rational dynamics. The first project for such a quantum dynamics was the pilot-wave theory of Louis de Broglie, according to which microscopic particles move in responseto a wave field generated by the particle's internal vibration. More than 80 years later, only 8 years ago, the first pilot-wave system was discovered by Yves Couder, in the form of millimetric drops walking along the surface of a vibrating fluid bath. Remarkably, these walking droplets exhibit many features thought to be peculiar to the microscopic world. In addition to being a rich and subtle dynamical system worthy of study in its own right, the walking droplets have the potential to yield insight into the microscopic realm. This research will explore both question and inform the philosophical foundations of modern physics. This research is interdisciplinary in nature, spanning fluid dynamics, dynamical systems and quantum physics, so will foster the development of new links between fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There have been four principal outcomes of this integrated experimental and theoretical project, Pilot-wave Hydrodynamics. First, we developed a state-of-the-art experimental rig that far outstrips it competitors, along with a robust droplet-on-demand generator and a surface Schlieren technique for quantitative measurements of the wave field accompanying the walkers. Second, we have gained considerable insight into the origins of quantization and wave-like statistics in the orbital dynamics of both single walkers in force fields, and free orbiting pairs. Quantization arises due to the dynamic constraint imposed on the walker by its pilot wave field, while the wave-like statistics reflect the persistent dynamical influence of the unstable orbital states. Third, we have developed a theoretical model capable of capturing walker-boundary interactions, thereby opening up the possibility of modeling a number of new hydrodynamic quantum analogs. Fourth, we have established the first connections between this hydrodynamic system, de Broglie's relativistic pilot-wave mechanics and its more recent extensions through researchers in stochastic electrodynamics. 

This walking droplet system represents the first example of a pilot-wave system, in which a particle is self-propelled through a resonant interaction with its own wave field. As a fluid mechanical system, it is rich and fascinating, an example of a particle moving in resonance with its own wave field. Characterizing the transitions to chaos in orbital pilot-wave dynamics has demonstrated the manner in which chaotic pilot-wave dynamics might underlie quantum-like statistical behavior. This hydrodynamic system suggests that de Broglie's pilot-wave theory, and the Hydrodynamic Interpretation of quantum mechanics, should both be reassessed and further developed. The demonstration that chaotic pilot-wave dynamics might underlie quantum statistics would represent a tremendous boon to the dynamical systems community. 

The fact that this hydrodynamic pilot-wave system exhibits quantum-like statistical behavior raises the question as to whether there really need be a philosophical schism between the microscopic and macroscopic worlds. One is currently taught that macroscopic physics is deterministic, with predictability limited only by the intrusion of chaos. Conversely, microscopic physics is thought to be intrinsically probabilistic, with the statistical predictions of quantum mechanics taken to be a complete description of the world of microscopic particles. This hydrodynamic system suggests that chaotic pilot-wave dynamics, now known to underlie quantum-like statistics on the macroscale, may also underlie quantum statistics. Such a conclusion would have enormous impact on the fields of modern physics and scientific philosophy. Our work is now being carefully followed and commented upon by a number of scientific philosophers. 

During the reporting period, we have published 24 articles on the subject of this hydrodynamic quantum analog system. Two of them have been high-profile reviews, one in Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics, the other in Physics Today. My research group and I have given over 50 talks on the subject as various conferences and seminars. Our work has also reached a broader audience through a number of public lectures and science bloggers, including Veritasium. On the strength of our resutls, I shall be guest-editing a special issue of Chaos on the subject of hydrodynamic quantum analogs this year, and writing an invited review for Reports on Progress in Physics. All of my research group, postdocs, graduate students and undergraduates, have benefitted from the richness of the problem, and the generous support of the NSF's CMMI program.
